quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: The way I learned how to pitch in business school, and I think the way most people did is what I call the arrogant doctor.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Names a common but flawed pitch pattern, giving practitioners a clear anti-pattern to avoid.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: So you have a problem, a pain, I have a solution, a treatment, and I'm going to tell you why it's better than all the other treatments.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Summarizes the default “problem-solution” pitch structure so teams can recognize when they’re relying on it.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Every movie starts with some kind of shift in the world, and I call this shift the shift from the old game to a new game.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Introduces a narrative framework practitioners can use to reframe pitches around a market change rather than a product feature set.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: So he comes in and he says, "Hey, software is over and there's this new world called the cloud, a new game, new rules. That's the new way to win. And we're going to help you if you're in there."
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Provides a concrete example (Salesforce/Benioff) of positioning via a “new game” shift that others can model.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: This structure really is about defining a movement, and that's very different from, "Hey, I'm going to solve your problem."
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Contrasts movement-based narrative with problem-solving pitches, challenging conventional go-to-market messaging.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: I use Coda every day to wrangle my newsletter content calendar, my interview notes for podcasts, and to coordinate my sponsors.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Concrete example of using a single tool as an operational hub across multiple workflows.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: More recently, I actually wrote a whole post on how Coda's product team operates, and within that post, they shared a dozen templates that they use internally to run their product team, including managing a roadmap, their OKR process, getting internal feedback, and essentially their whole product development process is done within Coda.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Specific, replicable playbook idea: standardize product operations via reusable templates spanning roadmap, OKRs, and feedback loops.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Coda puts data in one centralized location regardless of format, eliminating roadblocks that can slow your team down.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Actionable operational principle: centralize cross-format work artifacts to reduce coordination friction.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Thousands of people apply to join this collective, and I personally review and accept just about 10% of them.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Notable data point on curation/selectivity that signals quality control in a talent marketplace.

quotes.topic_title: Andy’s origin story: failing pitch to story craft
quotes.text: One VC wrote back and said, "Listen, I rate every plan I get on a scale of 1 to 10, and yours is a 1," and the next to the one he wrote in parentheses, "Worst," in case we thought maybe that was the top of his rating scale.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: A vivid data point showing how brutally a pitch can fail—and how clear feedback can trigger a rethink of narrative and structure.

quotes.topic_title: Andy’s origin story: failing pitch to story craft
quotes.text: And he had written in, "Not a compelling story."
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Pinpoints that the core pitch problem wasn’t features or market size, but narrative pull—useful as a diagnostic for practitioners.

quotes.topic_title: Andy’s origin story: failing pitch to story craft
quotes.text: I started reading these books and it strikes me a movie is a pitch.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Introduces a transferable mental model: treat your pitch like a structured narrative designed to persuade.

quotes.topic_title: Andy’s origin story: failing pitch to story craft
quotes.text: That we didn't change the product, it was basically the same business just sort of how we talked about it.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Counterintuitive lesson that messaging and structure can unlock traction even when the underlying product is unchanged.

quotes.topic_title: Andy’s origin story: failing pitch to story craft
quotes.text: "No. No CEO's going to budget a line item for the story. That's not a thing."
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Highlights a common (often wrong) assumption that “story” isn’t a fundable business priority—useful for reframing narrative work as strategic.

quotes.topic_title: Writing and solving your own problem
quotes.text: One is that interesting opportunities arise when you're doing something you're excited about.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a practical career heuristic: follow genuine excitement because it tends to surface unexpected opportunities.

quotes.topic_title: Writing and solving your own problem
quotes.text: So you had the startup, it didn't work out, but you had a problem that you solved for yourself and that led to another, a bigger opportunity for your career.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concrete example of turning a failed venture into career leverage by solving a real personal problem.

quotes.topic_title: Writing and solving your own problem
quotes.text: And then also just some of the best opportunities arise from solving your own problem, not planning to start something with it, but just like, "I have a problem."
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Counterintuitive guidance: don’t force a startup idea—solve your own pain first and let opportunities emerge.

quotes.topic_title: Writing and solving your own problem
quotes.text: Yeah, that's how it goes. It always overnight for everyone else that isn't here.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A memorable reframing of “overnight success” as an outsider illusion, useful for setting realistic expectations.

quotes.topic_title: What a strategic narrative is
quotes.text: The one thing I say is it's this one story that the CEO uses to drive success in marketing, sales, but also product. That it becomes like a north star, strategic north star for product roadmap, for fundraising, for recruiting, really everything.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Defines strategic narrative as a single CEO-level story that aligns and guides multiple functions, not just marketing.

quotes.topic_title: What a strategic narrative is
quotes.text: And the traditional structure, the way I learned how to pitch in business school, I think the way most people did is what I call the arrogant doctor. So you have a problem, a pain, I have a solution, a treatment, and I'm going to tell you why it's better than all the other treatment.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Names and critiques the conventional problem-solution pitch as a limiting default framework.

quotes.topic_title: What a strategic narrative is
quotes.text: In the movies, every movie starts with some kind of shift in the world, in the character's world. And I call this shift the shift from the old game to the new game.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Introduces a narrative structure practitioners can apply: anchor the story in a world shift rather than a product claim.

quotes.topic_title: What a strategic narrative is
quotes.text: So he comes in and he says, "Hey, software is over," meaning software in the sense that we're going to own it and maintain it, "And there's this new world called the cloud, a new game, like the new rules, everything has changed and that's the new way to win. And we're going to help you if you're in there."
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Concrete example (Salesforce/Benioff) of framing a strategic narrative as a movement around a new game.

quotes.topic_title: What a strategic narrative is
quotes.text: This structure really is about defining a movement and that's very different from, "Hey, I'm going to solve your problem."
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Distills the key counterpoint: movement narratives outperform problem-solution pitches by changing the frame of the market.

quotes.topic_title: Salesforce example: old game vs new game
quotes.text: And so they would've come and said, "Oh, we're easier to install, faster to get up and running than Siebel," or, "We have this much functionality compared to,"
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Shows the default, feature-comparison playbook Salesforce could have followed—and what strategic narrative helps you avoid.

quotes.topic_title: Salesforce example: old game vs new game
quotes.text: They led with this story about this fundamental paradigm shift and, are you in or are you not in?
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: A crisp framework for positioning: lead with a market shift and force a binary choice rather than incremental differentiation.

quotes.topic_title: Salesforce example: old game vs new game
quotes.text: And what they did was instead of just saying, "Hey, we're better than," they said, "Hey, all those others, those Siebel's, they're part of that old game. You want to play that software game? Be my guest, go buy Siebel,"
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Actionable positioning move: reclassify incumbents as “old game” to change evaluation criteria and buyer identity.

quotes.topic_title: Salesforce example: old game vs new game
quotes.text: So the crux of the approach is instead of, "Problem, solution, you should go do this," it's, "The world is changing, here's where it's going and we're going to help you get there."
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Summarizes the strategic narrative methodology as a shift from solution-selling to future-state leadership.

quotes.topic_title: More examples: Zuora and Gong narratives
quotes.text: So the crux of the approach is instead of, "Problem, solution, you should go do this," it's, "The world is changing, here's where it's going and we're going to help you get there."
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A clear positioning framework: lead with a market shift and destination, not a feature/problem pitch.

quotes.topic_title: More examples: Zuora and Gong narratives
quotes.text: And he's pitching, "Hey, in the old world, businesses operated on transactions. You sold things to people outright. In this new world," he calls it the subscription economy, where people want the benefits of those things without necessarily having to pay for them.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: A concrete example of structuring narrative as an “old world vs new world” shift with a named movement.

quotes.topic_title: More examples: Zuora and Gong narratives
quotes.text: And that story is, hey, goodbye opinions. Used to be a world where sales is run on opinions. Hello reality, that now all the winners are adopting this new mindset where we really have to see what's really going on.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: A memorable, repeatable narrative hook that reframes a product as a mindset change and competitive necessity.

quotes.topic_title: More examples: Zuora and Gong narratives
quotes.text: We're going to be a huge company. The question is how huge. And I think that this narrative along the lines of Zuora or Salesforce, if we get this right, this is going to be a multiplier on our growth.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: A practical claim about narrative as a growth lever—getting the story right can amplify outcomes beyond incremental improvements.

quotes.topic_title: More examples: Zuora and Gong narratives
quotes.text: There wasn't this kind of unifying kind of movement ideology that put it all in context.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Highlights what typical product pitches miss: a unifying movement/ideology that contextualizes features into a bigger shift.

quotes.topic_title: Impact of Andy’s viral Zuora sales deck post
quotes.text: that post immediately got something like 2 million views around the world and I started getting inquiries from teams all over the world.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: A concrete data point showing how a single high-leverage piece of writing can drive massive reach and inbound demand.

quotes.topic_title: Impact of Andy’s viral Zuora sales deck post
quotes.text: And it was I think what really allowed me to say no, okay, I could do this work. That CEO's would budget a line item for this.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Highlights a practical validation test: inbound response can prove buyers will explicitly fund narrative work.

quotes.topic_title: Impact of Andy’s viral Zuora sales deck post
quotes.text: Because I think if you really understand that post, it's not really about a sales deck, it's really about this story that Tien, the CEO is telling everywhere and that is showing up in the sales deck and structuring it that way.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Reframes “great decks” as downstream artifacts of a consistent CEO narrative, offering a repeatable way to build sales materials.

quotes.topic_title: Impact of Andy’s viral Zuora sales deck post
quotes.text: And when you work with a great editor, it's great, they make yourself better and they're priceless. But still there's this intermediary.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: A counterintuitive tradeoff: editorial quality can come with distribution gatekeeping that creators may want to bypass.

quotes.topic_title: Impact of Andy’s viral Zuora sales deck post
quotes.text: What started to happen, I think around when I started writing around 2013, '14, you start to see these platforms, like Medium, even LinkedIn where you can just write and have this audience and I think no way I could do this, the work I do if that development hadn't happened first.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Points to a practical go-to-market lever for experts: direct distribution platforms can enable an entire services business.

quotes.topic_title: Consistency vs viral hits in writing
quotes.text: So that was probably the 30th or 40th piece and they were gradually getting more and more traction.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Reframes “overnight success” as the result of sustained iteration and compounding distribution over many attempts.

quotes.topic_title: Consistency vs viral hits in writing
quotes.text: So what I find is like, yeah, there's this a while where you're writing and it feels like you're talking to nobody and then gradually it grows and you'll have these peaks, but then over time is where the magic is.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: A practical mental model for content growth: expect a quiet phase, then intermittent spikes, with long-term consistency driving results.

quotes.topic_title: Consistency vs viral hits in writing
quotes.text: There was one I wrote before that about, it's kind of dissecting Elon Musk's pitch for the Powerwall, the battery that they sell. And that one got maybe few hundred thousand views and also was a big jump.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Concrete example showing “breakout” posts often come in stages—one big jump can precede a larger one.

quotes.topic_title: Consistency vs viral hits in writing
quotes.text: I haven't done a newsletter because that idea of having a deadline all the time and constantly having to, we used to call the magazine Feed the Beast, I feel so free not to have that.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Counterintuitive advice: avoiding recurring deadlines can preserve creative freedom and sustainability for some writers.

quotes.topic_title: Strategic narrative framework: five core parts
quotes.text: What's really, I think key is naming it, naming that old game.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Emphasizes that a strategic narrative starts by crisply labeling the prior paradigm rather than listing generic changes.

quotes.topic_title: Strategic narrative framework: five core parts
quotes.text: This very, very concise naming is really key.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Actionable guidance to compress the shift into a short, memorable label that people can repeat.

quotes.topic_title: Strategic narrative framework: five core parts
quotes.text: So we're always kind of overstating it in a way, but it's not a problem.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Counterintuitive permission to simplify and even overstate the shift to make the narrative stick.

quotes.topic_title: Strategic narrative framework: five core parts
quotes.text: This is for me the definition, is that the prospect doesn't see the future as sort of okay. They see it as split between a very negative outcome and a potentially very positive outcome.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Defines “emotional stakes” in practical terms: create a clear fork between loss and upside rather than mild improvement.

quotes.topic_title: Strategic narrative framework: five core parts
quotes.text: I find that what's the object of the new game really boils it down as kind of the rallying cry of the movement.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Introduces a concrete component of the framework: a short mission-like phrase that captures what winning the new game means.

quotes.topic_title: Hero’s journey: useful but not the focus
quotes.text: But even that aside, I found when I would talk about hero's journey and stuff, it's just like, it didn't really tell me what to do.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: A contrarian reminder that popular storytelling templates can be too abstract to guide real-world pitching decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Hero’s journey: useful but not the focus
quotes.text: I'm not really interested in that in my work, what I'm interested in is the one story and the structure of that one story.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Shifts focus from generic storytelling skill-building to designing a single strategic narrative for a specific sales context.

quotes.topic_title: Hero’s journey: useful but not the focus
quotes.text: It's almost as if what's happening is we're turning the person we talk to into the main character.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: A practical mental model for strategic narrative: make the buyer the hero rather than positioning your company as the protagonist.

quotes.topic_title: Hero’s journey: useful but not the focus
quotes.text: And by the way, the naming of the object of the new game, I find it often is really nice to do it as a question.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Actionable tactic for pitches: frame the “new game” as a question to invite participation and alignment.

quotes.topic_title: Hero’s journey: useful but not the focus
quotes.text: So we asked a simple question, what would it take to turn every customer into a subscriber?
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Concrete example of the question-framing technique that pulls the audience into co-creating the narrative.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Last month Eco users earned an average of $84 in cash back rewards.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concrete performance data point that makes the value proposition tangible and measurable.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Eco is the update to a misaligned financial system providing an app that works just like your bank but removes almost all of the middlemen, helping even the best money optimizers optimize in less time automatically.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A positioning template: same familiar behavior (“works just like your bank”) plus a clear structural differentiator (“removes... middlemen”) tied to a user outcome (time saved).

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Maybe just to reinforce this even more, what if we go through the five steps and just with one company as an example and just talk about what each of those were for them?
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A practical facilitation move: apply an abstract framework by walking through it with a single concrete case.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: So there's a company called 360Learning. So this company, I don't know if folks know, but this company is raised over $200 million.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: A specific example anchored by a credibility/data point that signals the case study is substantial and worth learning from.

quotes.topic_title: Case study: 360Learning narrative rebuild
quotes.text: And so when we worked together this collaborative learning, it's almost like a category name or a descriptor or something. They were so embedded that I decided, I don't even want to take it out, but can we define it in terms of a story?
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Shows a practical reframing move: keep the familiar category label, but make it meaningful by anchoring it in a narrative.

quotes.topic_title: Case study: 360Learning narrative rebuild
quotes.text: So the story they came to was, hey, used to be that companies train their people through basically a mindset of top-down learning.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Demonstrates the “old world vs new world” narrative structure that creates contrast and momentum in a pitch.

quotes.topic_title: Case study: 360Learning narrative rebuild
quotes.text: What's happening now is winning companies are approaching this differently. They're adopting this approach we might call upskill from within, which is if you look at Google, there's this page where I think you can go, it's a public. You can connect with Google's AI experts.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Pairs a named shift (“upskill from within”) with a concrete winner example (Google) to make the change feel real and urgent.

quotes.topic_title: Case study: 360Learning narrative rebuild
quotes.text: Nick was in France and he saw this poster, a recruiting poster from McDonald's and it said, "Hey, if you work at McDonald's you're going to learn from everybody else on your team."
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: A memorable proof point that even non-obvious “winners” can validate the narrative shift and make it stick.

quotes.topic_title: Case study: 360Learning narrative rebuild
quotes.text: he was telling me it's just like when he starts with this now he doesn't even get the question anymore of well how are you different from this other learning platform? Which used to always be the thing.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Highlights an outcome metric practitioners can look for: a strong narrative can eliminate commodity comparison questions.

quotes.topic_title: Business impact: marketing and product alignment
quotes.text: One is that when they're pitching, they're not pitching features out of context, they're pitching now a movement which is a lot better place to be, I think.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Reframes go-to-market from feature selling to movement selling, a practical shift in how teams structure pitches.

quotes.topic_title: Business impact: marketing and product alignment
quotes.text: In a way you're not pitching product. Product is like a prop for making the story come true.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for aligning marketing and product around a narrative where the product supports the story, not vice versa.

quotes.topic_title: Business impact: marketing and product alignment
quotes.text: With Zuora, if you look at their website, well when they first started doing this, maybe 80% of the content is not, "Hey, let me tell you about how Zuora is so great," or, "Here's our new release," or whatever. It's, "Here's how music companies are embracing subscriptions. Here's how luxury goods companies are embracing subscriptions."
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Concrete example of using strategic narrative to power a thought-leadership content engine rather than product-centric marketing.

quotes.topic_title: Business impact: marketing and product alignment
quotes.text: He said, "We are constantly getting feature requests through sales, through customer success. And we had sort of no way, bar to decide well what do we take on, what don't we take on? And this clearly has become our bar."
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Shows how a strategic narrative can become a product prioritization filter that aligns teams and reduces reactive roadmap decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Business impact: marketing and product alignment
quotes.text: "We get a lot of requests for features and a lot of them are basically about opinions, some way to record opinions."
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Specific example of identifying a class of feature requests that may not fit the narrative-driven product strategy.

quotes.topic_title: Strong narrative example: Drift’s conversational marketing
quotes.text: Drift comes out with essentially like a chatbot for your website, which might be the 30th chatbot for your website. And they don't say, "Hey, here's why our chatbot is the best one." They start from a completely different place, which is, "Hey, used to be people would sort of wait around for you to get back to them. It was a world of later. They called it the world of forms."
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Shows a contrarian positioning move: don’t compete on product superiority—reframe the buyer’s world with a new lens.

quotes.topic_title: Strong narrative example: Drift’s conversational marketing
quotes.text: You put up a web form and you expect someone's going to fill it out and maybe wait a few days while you take your sweet time deciding if you're going to get back to them.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: A vivid articulation of the “old world” pain that makes the narrative emotionally resonant and easy to recognize.

quotes.topic_title: Strong narrative example: Drift’s conversational marketing
quotes.text: Now we're in a world of now, where buyers are ...
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Captures the core narrative pivot: define a new “current reality” that changes expectations and urgency.

quotes.topic_title: Strong narrative example: Drift’s conversational marketing
quotes.text: That's your prospect. They're always on and they're going to expect you to be engaging with them right away.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Actionable buyer-expectation insight: modern prospects demand immediate engagement, shaping product and go-to-market choices.

quotes.topic_title: Strong narrative example: Drift’s conversational marketing
quotes.text: And they called this conversational marketing, and they really went with that and created I think a whole movement and they broke away from all of the other chatbots.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Illustrates how naming + committing to a narrative can create a movement and differentiation even in a crowded market.

quotes.topic_title: Category creation vs movement narrative
quotes.text: what I find though is that when people think about category creation, they tend to just focus on, okay, well, what is this category name going to be that we got? What are these three words or two words, whatever, that are going to magically make us seem like we're totally different from everybody else?
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Challenges the common “name the category” obsession and reframes differentiation as narrative-driven rather than label-driven.

quotes.topic_title: Category creation vs movement narrative
quotes.text: Take Gong, I mean already other companies were using this term revenue intelligence. With Gong, it suddenly becomes a thing because I think they have this opinions-to-reality story behind it.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Concrete example showing how a compelling story can make an existing label feel like a real category.

quotes.topic_title: Category creation vs movement narrative
quotes.text: "Yeah, you know what? In hindsight we probably could have called it strawberry intelligence. It didn't matter. It was really the story that sort of mattered."
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Memorable line that underscores how category naming is often far less important than the underlying strategic narrative.

quotes.topic_title: Category creation vs movement narrative
quotes.text: So my feeling is like, well, let's focus on the story. So that's why I talk about strategic narrative and movement creation versus category creation. If someone decides that your movement is a category, great. Bonus.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Actionable prioritization: build the movement/story first and treat category status as an optional outcome.

quotes.topic_title: Category creation vs movement narrative
quotes.text: But this movement is the thing that's sort of the constant and in some ways orthogonal to whatever category they're in.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: A mental model for practitioners: movement narrative can remain stable even as the company’s category label changes over time.

quotes.topic_title: Where strategic narrative fits best
quotes.text: So I think it does really play well in this enterprise sales context because also we have a group buyer there. So it's not just one person who's doing some research. This whole group has to have a uniting story.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Highlights when strategic narrative is most effective: complex enterprise deals with multiple stakeholders who need a shared storyline to align decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Where strategic narrative fits best
quotes.text: So I think you're right that in noticing that the companies that this tends to resonate with tend to be B2B, enterprise sales, technology I think because often the product is very complicated.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Gives a practical fit test: the more complex the B2B product and sale, the more leverage you get from narrative over feature explanation.

quotes.topic_title: Where strategic narrative fits best
quotes.text: B2B software, this stuff is changing by the minute. And does it even make sense to make a claim to say, "Oh, we have these features and they have those features, therefore we're better," does that make any sense?
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Challenges feature-comparison positioning in fast-evolving software markets, implying narrative is a more durable differentiator than specs.

quotes.topic_title: Where strategic narrative fits best
quotes.text: That said, hey, I was looking for a sports watch, a Fitbit and I'm comparing specs and I'm doing all that stuff. And so that mode of buying is still happening, but I think, so yeah, when consumer products companies contact me, I usually say, "No."
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Provides a concrete boundary condition: many consumer purchases remain spec-driven, so strategic narrative may be lower ROI there.

quotes.topic_title: Where strategic narrative fits best
quotes.text: But yeah, I think it has the most value, most impactful right away for B2B enterprise technology companies.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Summarizes the “sweet spot” where teams should prioritize investing in strategic narrative first for maximum immediate impact.

quotes.topic_title: When you need a narrative: scaling, expansion, pivots
quotes.text: So a few things they tell me, one is that the company is maturing from a point a stage where they've been successful, but that success is ... one CEO put it this way, was brute force of the founders.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Highlights a common trigger for needing a strategic narrative: founder-driven momentum stops scaling as the org grows.

quotes.topic_title: When you need a narrative: scaling, expansion, pivots
quotes.text: Usually I'm seeing this around series B where the company is getting ... so they can't be in every sales call, every market call and they're looking to transmit all the good stuff and some direction in a way that people are going to remember and all that.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Gives a practical timing signal (around Series B) and the core job of narrative: scalable, memorable direction-setting.

quotes.topic_title: When you need a narrative: scaling, expansion, pivots
quotes.text: Now we're either acquiring or building out whole new product units. And that old story we told is just, it's just not big enough and we got to expand it to something bigger.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Provides a clear heuristic: multi-product expansion or M&A often breaks the old story and demands a bigger narrative container.

quotes.topic_title: When you need a narrative: scaling, expansion, pivots
quotes.text: This is the example of OneTrust, which the CEO I had on my podcast recently. Starts out with just, I think it's data privacy around the regulations that people have to be able to say, "Don't track me," things like that. And then they buy these other company and now we have this much bigger offering. So how do we tell the story?
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Concrete example of a company outgrowing its initial narrative after acquisitions broaden the product scope.

quotes.topic_title: When you need a narrative: scaling, expansion, pivots
quotes.text: And then I guess the third one is some form of pivot where hey, we were telling an old story but whatever, the market changed or whatever and we want to go in a different direction.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Names pivoting due to market change as a third trigger—when the old narrative no longer matches reality, it must be rewritten.

quotes.topic_title: How to start: draft, test in calls, avoid templates
quotes.text: I want to get that thing out there into sales calls. We're not rolling it out to the whole sales team right away, but getting it out into some sales calls and get a sense, "Hey, is this resonating? Are people given the nods?"
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Advocates a lean, iterative approach: test the narrative in real calls before a full rollout to validate resonance quickly.

quotes.topic_title: How to start: draft, test in calls, avoid templates
quotes.text: Ideally by the way, one way I look to test it, is it working, is when we talk about this shift and the stakes and do they stick.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Provides a concrete validation criterion—whether prospects latch onto the “shift and stakes”—to judge if the narrative is working.

quotes.topic_title: How to start: draft, test in calls, avoid templates
quotes.text: Sometimes I'll literally, I'll train salespeople to ask them that question, like, "Am I crazy or are you seeing this?"
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Gives a practical prompt sales teams can use to elicit prospect confirmation and engagement with the narrative’s core shift.

quotes.topic_title: How to start: draft, test in calls, avoid templates
quotes.text: And I am so against this template. Every team I work with, it's different.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Challenges the common desire for plug-and-play decks, emphasizing that strategic narratives must be tailored to each team and situation.

quotes.topic_title: How to start: draft, test in calls, avoid templates
quotes.text: And what I'd say is these are principles for building it, not any prescribed formula.
quotes.speaker: Andy Raskin
quotes.context: Reframes the work as principle-driven design rather than following a fixed template, encouraging adaptation and iteration.
